name: Cell Biology
understandings: According to cell theory, living organisms are composed of cells
Organisms consisting of only one cell carry out all functions of life in that cell
Surface area to volume ratio is important in the limitation of cell size
Multicellular organisms have properties that emerge from the interaction of their cellular components
Specialized tissues can develop by cell differentiation in multicellular organisms
Differentiation involves the expression of some genes and not others in a cell's genome
The capacity of stem cells to divide and differentiate makes them suitable for therapeutic uses
applications: Questioning the cell theory using atypical examples including striated muscle, giant algae and aseptate fungal hyphae
Investigation of functions of life in Paramecium and one named photosynthetic unicellular organism
Use of stem cells to treat Stargardt's disease and one other named condition
Ethics of the therapeutic use of stem cells from specially created embryos, umbilical cord blood and adult tissues

keyConcepts.definition: The theory that all living organisms are made up of cells, all cells come from pre-existing cells, and the cell is the basic unit of life
keyConcepts.importance: Foundation of modern biology - explains how all life is organized

keyConcepts.definition: The ratio between the surface area and volume of a cell, which decreases as cell size increases
keyConcepts.importance: Limits cell size because exchange of materials becomes insufficient as volume increases faster than surface area

keyConcepts.definition: Undifferentiated cells capable of self-renewal and differentiation into specialized cell types
keyConcepts.importance: Have therapeutic potential for treating diseases and repairing damaged tissues

keyConcepts.definition: The process by which a cell becomes specialized for a particular function
keyConcepts.importance: Allows multicellular organisms to have specialized tissues and organs with specific functions

keyConcepts.definition: Properties that arise from the interaction of components that are not present in the individual components
keyConcepts.importance: Explains how multicellular organisms can have functions that individual cells cannot perform

commonMisconceptions.correction: Prokaryotic cells (bacteria and archaea) do not have a membrane-bound nucleus. Red blood cells in mammals also lack nuclei.
Cell size is relatively constant across organisms. Larger organisms have more cells, not larger cells.

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Stem cells only come from embryos
commonMisconceptions.correction: Stem cells can be obtained from embryos, umbilical cord blood, and adult tissues. Adult stem cells are found in bone marrow and other tissues.

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Cell theory applies perfectly to all living things
commonMisconceptions.correction: There are exceptions like striated muscle fibers (multinucleate), giant algae (Acetabularia), and aseptate fungal hyphae that challenge the theory.

Surface area to volume ratio calculations and implications
Ethical considerations of stem cell research
typicalQuestions: Outline the cell theory and discuss one exception to it
Explain why cells cannot grow beyond a certain size
Discuss the ethical issues surrounding the use of embryonic stem cells
Compare and contrast prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells
markingNotes: Award marks for specific named examples, not generic statements
Cell theory questions require all three principles to be stated for full marks
SA:V ratio questions often require mathematical reasoning
Ethics questions need balanced arguments with specific points
commonMistakes: Confusing prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell features
Not providing specific examples when required
Forgetting to mention all three principles of cell theory

connections.relationship: Molecular biology explains the chemical basis of cell structure and function
Genetics explains how cell differentiation is controlled by gene expression
Human physiology examines specialized cells in tissues and organs

understandings: The cell cycle and its phases including interphase and mitosis
Cyclins are involved in the control of the cell cycle
Mitosis is division of the nucleus into two genetically identical daughter nuclei
Chromosomes condense by supercoiling during mitosis
applications: The correlation between smoking and incidence of cancers
Identification of phases of mitosis in cells viewed with a microscope or in a micrograph

keyConcepts.definition: Asexual reproduction in prokaryotes where one cell divides into two identical daughter cells
The sequence of events from one cell division to the next, including interphase (G1, S, G2) and mitosis
Regulatory proteins that control the cell cycle by activating cyclin-dependent kinases
keyConcepts.importance: Ensure proper progression through cell cycle; mutations can lead to cancer
